topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open highlights Wes’s philosophy of taking responsibility for confusion and previewing frameworks like MOO. Lenny introduces Wes’s background (altMBA, Maven) and sets up the episode’s focus on executive communication and influence.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for WorkOS and Vanta, covering enterprise auth/authorization and compliance automation.

topics.title: Why communication is high-leverage for leaders
topics.summary: Lenny frames communication as core to leadership (“Communication is the job”) and shares testimonials about Wes’s precision and teaching. Wes sets the stage for tactical frameworks to improve influence and clarity.

topics.title: Agency: if they don’t get it, adjust you
topics.summary: Wes argues many misunderstandings are avoidable and encourages reflecting on how you contributed when others are confused or apathetic. Communication is treated as a learnable skill that increases odds of getting the outcome you want.

topics.title: Practice like it’s game day with everyone
topics.summary: Wes warns against saving “best communication” only for executives; you need reps with all stakeholders. Respecting everyone’s time and consistently communicating well builds executive-level skill faster.

topics.title: What counts as communication: verbal, written, outcomes
topics.summary: They define communication mediums (verbal vs written) and emphasize communication as a means to an end—buy-in, decisions, and next steps—rather than an end in itself.

topics.title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in before details
topics.summary: Wes explains the common mistake of jumping into process details before the audience agrees the idea is worth doing. She shares an ops example (weekly wins) and how leading with “why/benefit” increases response and alignment.

topics.title: Concise framing for execs and “yes, next” mindset
topics.summary: Wes describes how leaders often decide quickly and want to move on; presenters should take the win and not over-talk. She recommends a short upfront frame: why we’re here + what you need from them.

topics.title: Being concise: clarity of thinking and preparation
topics.summary: Concision is framed as density of insight, not word count; the real bottleneck is not knowing the core point. Preparation—even 30–60 seconds before meetings—improves focus, brevity, and flexibility.

topics.title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load, blast radius
topics.summary: Wes advises rereading and explicitly asking how to reduce cognitive load; small edits often cut ~20% and prevent confusion. She introduces the “blast radius” idea: unclear memos create costly back-and-forth across many readers.

topics.title: Signposting and formatting: guide attention without clutter
topics.summary: They discuss signposting words/phrases (e.g., “because,” “for example,” “next step,” “first/second/third”) for structure in writing and speech. Wes cautions against excessive bolding and bullet fragments that force readers to infer logic.

topics.title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
topics.summary: Wes suggests a feedback loop: track how quickly you get the reaction/outcome you want and whether back-and-forth decreases. Improve by experimenting, focusing on one tactic at a time, and avoiding overwhelm.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Coda, describing an all-in-one collaborative workspace for docs, trackers, and workflows.

topics.title: Confidence calibration: speak accurately about certainty
topics.summary: Wes explains pitfalls of overconfidence (stating hypotheses as facts) and underconfidence (over-disclaiming strong recommendations). The solution is accurate language about conviction plus reasoning/evidence so others can evaluate and respond.
